nodes.text: Conservation of money in agent-to-agent transactions, analyzed with statistical physics methods, explains the emergence of an exponential distribution of money (and consequent inequality), clarifies roles of debt and banking, and links state money creation to capitalist profit and observed income inequality
Statistical physics concepts and tools (ensembles, entropy maximization, kinetic equations) are applicable to economic ensembles of interacting agents
Money functions as a conserved digital accounting token in peer transactions (local conservation m1'+m2'=m1+m2) and is necessary to prevent free riding

Modeling methodology: use Boltzmann kinetic equation for pairwise transfers and its small-Delta limit, the Fokker-Planck (Kolmogorov forward) equation, with drift A and diffusion B determined by moments of transfer amounts

Result: For conserved money with additive transfers or time-reversal symmetric microscopic rules, the stationary distribution of money is exponential P(m) proportional to exp(-m/Tm), with Tm = mean money per agent

Claim: When microscopic transactions are multiplicative (transfer proportional to agent balance) or break time-reversal symmetry, stationary distributions become Gamma-like with power-law tails rather than pure exponential

Evidence: Empirical income data (U.S. Census and IRS) show a two-class structure: lower majority follows an exponential distribution, upper tail follows a Pareto power law; high-end share grows during market bubbles and quantitative easing
Claim: The exponential distribution is the maximum-entropy outcome under a fixed total money constraint and entropy increases monotonically under the kinetic dynamics

Claim: Debt creation (IOUs) is distinct from money; allowing unrestricted debt removes the lower boundary (net-worth can go negative), prevents equilibrium, leads to unbounded spreading of net-worth distribution, and requires explicit debt limits to stabilize

Claim: Commercial banks create debt-liabilities for customers (appear to 'create money' in deposits) but do not exogenously create base money; central banks (state) perform exogenous money creation via bond purchases and monetization

Claim: The lend-crash-bailout cycle (endogenous bank-created credit expansion followed by crises and central-bank monetization) transfers newly created state money disproportionately to financial actors and increases income and wealth inequality

Evidence: Time series analysis of US income (1983-2013) shows spikes in upper-tail income share and Gini coefficient coincident with speculative bubbles (dot-com, housing) and quantitative easing, supporting the link between monetary interventions and rising inequality

Claim: Wealth (money plus monetary valuation of goods) is conceptually different from money; wealth changes between transactions via price or volume changes, so conservative kinetic models labeled 'wealth transfer' are misleading unless they explicitly model prices and production

Assumption / Method: Distinguish two coupled layers: physical layer (production, nonconserved goods governed by physics/energy) and monetary/informational layer (conserved numeric accounts); money mediates exchanges but is not converted into physical goods

Conclusion: The ultimate source of aggregate capitalist monetary profit and ability to sustain universal interest payments is exogenous state money creation (monetization/bailouts); without state injection, aggregate net monetary profits are constrained by conservation and debt dynamics

Limitation / Open problem: Existing kinetic and mean-field models do not capture synchronized, correlated debt crises, the switching dynamics (Minsky cycles), or changing transaction topology in a digital economy; modeling these collective nonstationary phenomena remains an open research challenge
